Location.summary: The Location interface represents the location (URL) of the object it is linked to. Changes done on it are reflected on the object it relates to. Both the and interface have such a linked Location, accessible via and respectively.

remarks.para:
-Two Location properties: and .
-URL manipulation interfaces: and .

LocationSearch.summary: The search property of the interface is a search string, also called a query string, that is a string containing a "?" followed by the parameters of the location's URL. If the URL does not have a search query, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the query string of the URL. When setting, a single "?" prefix is added to the provided value, if not already present. Setting it to "" removes the query string.
The query is Percent-encoding when setting but not percent-decoded when reading.

Modern browsers provide
URLSearchParams
and
URL.searchParams
to make it easy to parse out the parameters from the querystring.
See for more information.

LocationPathname.summary:
The pathname property of the
interface is a string containing the path of the URL for the location. If there is no path, pathname will be empty: otherwise, pathname contains an initial '/' followed by the path of the URL, not including the query string or fragment.

LocationOrigin.summary: The origin read-only property of the interface returns a string containing the Unicode serialization of the origin of the location's URL.

remarks.para: The exact structure varies depending on the type of URL:
For all other cases, the string "null" is returned.
See for more information.

-Window.origin
-origin glossary term

LocationHost.summary: The host property of the interface is a string containing the host, which is the , and then, if the {{glossary("port")}} of the URL is nonempty, a ":", followed by the of the URL. If the URL does not have a hostname, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: See for more information.

LocationToString.summary:
The toString() stringifier method of the
interface returns a string containing the
whole URL. It is a read-only version of .
LocationToString.returns: A string representing the object's URL.

LocationProtocol.summary: The protocol property of the interface is a string containing the protocol or scheme of the location's URL, including the final ":".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the protocol of the URL. A ":" is appended to the provided string if not provided. The provided scheme has to be compatible with the rest of the URL to be considered valid.
See for more information.

LocationReplace.summary:
The replace() method of the
interface replaces the current resource with the one at the provided URL. The difference
from the method is that after using
replace() the current page will not be saved in session ,
meaning the user won't be able to use the back button to navigate to it.
Not to be confused with the method .

remarks.para:
-The interface it belongs to.
-Similar methods: and
.

LocationHref.summary:
The href property of the
interface is a stringifier that returns a string containing the whole
URL, and allows the href to be updated.

remarks.para:
Setting the value of href navigates to the provided URL. If you
want redirection, use . The difference from setting the href property value is that when using the location.replace() method, after navigating to the given URL, the current page will not be saved in session history â€” meaning the user won't be able to use the back button to navigate to it.

LocationAssign.summary:
The assign() method of the
interface causes the window to load
and display the document at the URL specified. After the navigation occurs, the user can
navigate back to the page that called Location.assign() by pressing the "back" button.

remarks.para:
-The interface it belongs to.
-Similar methods: and
.

LocationAncestorOrigins.summary:
The ancestorOrigins read-only
property of the interface is a static
containing, in reverse order, the origins of all ancestor
browsing contexts of the document associated with the given
object.

remarks.para:
You can use location.ancestorOrigins in the script for a document to
determine, for example, whenever the document is being framed by a site which you don't
expect it to be framed by. You can also use it to vary the behavior of the document
based on what site or list of sites is framing it.

LocationPort.summary: The port property of the interface is a string containing the port number of the location's URL. If the port is the default for the protocol (80 for ws: and http:, 443 for wss: and https:, and 21 for ftp:), this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the port of the URL. If the URL has no or its scheme is file:, then setting this property has no effect. It also silently ignores invalid port numbers.
See for more information.

LocationHash.summary: The hash property of the interface is a string containing a "#" followed by the fragment identifier of the location URL. If the URL does not have a fragment identifier, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: See for more information.

LocationReload.summary: The reload() method of the interface reloads the current URL, like the Refresh button.

remarks.para:
-The interface it belongs to.
-Similar methods: and
.

LocationHostname.summary: The hostname property of the interface is a string containing either the {{glossary("domain name")}} or {{glossary("IP address")}} of the location URL. If the URL does not have a hostname, this property contains an empty string, "". IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are normalized, such as stripping leading zeros, and domain names are converted to IDN.

remarks.para: See for more information.
